player/rules/house-rules.html.title: House Rules
player/rules/house-rules.html.description:
The campaign will start at level 1 for everyone. Everyone uses Point Buy Player Point Buy Worksheet Everyone starts with 27 points. One ability should intentionally be weaker than the others. Full rebuilds are allowed until the start of Session 2. After this it will have to work narratively with DM approval after this. I'm not opposed to character changes but I'd like to avoid destabilizing the party in the process.
Starting Gold and Equipment – D&D Basic RulesShould a new character need to join us in the middle of the campaign, we will most likely start that character at current player character levels unless the narrative and player/dm agree otherwise.This campaign uses standard D&D 5e rules for falling unconscious and death saving throws.Character death is a real possibility. Choices matter, combat can be dangerous, and caution is sometimes the wiser path. Without meaningful consequences, there is no reason to be careful.Resurrection magic exists in the world but follows normal rules. Time limits apply, required spells must be available, and material costs are in line with published rules. Not every death will be easily reversible, and resurrection is never guaranteed to be immediate or convenient.If a character dies, we will handle it respectfully and collaboratively. Options may include resurrection if circumstances allow, introducing a new character, or weaving the loss into the story in a meaningful way.The goal is not to punish players, but to ensure tension, stakes, and emotional weight remain part of the game.Experience will be done through Milestones, I.E. when the DM says you level up... we level your characters up. This will typically be done at the tail end of a session so anyone who needs help doing so may stay after and get the help they need. We will use the optional flanking rules in combat.When two allies are positioned on opposite sides of a creature and both can attack it, they gain advantage on melee attacks against that creature. This applies equally to player characters and enemies.Positioning and movement matter. Enemies will use flanking when it makes sense, just as players can.
When leveling players will have the choice to either take the default HP increase or roll their hit points at the table (Hit Point Increases in D&D 5e), should you roll a 1 you may re-roll once per level.
Choose your Alignment carefully, I'd like to use these as a guide for how your character will react in situations
Racial Bonuses will be used as written in the 5e Players handbook (Racial Ability Score Increases – D&D Basic Rules)We will not be strictly using encumbrance, but I will likely slow you down some if you start carrying around something which is obviously going to slow you down...We will be using the formula (2 x dice) + mod. Will depending on narrative cause a fumble which may, harm you or someone else you didn't intend, drop a weapon... things like this. I won't be breaking weapons etc. on you. The DM may award Inspiration for exceptional role playing, meaningful character driven choices, or moments that strongly reflect a character’s values.Inspiration can be spent to gain advantage on a single roll and does not stack. For most situations, up to two different characters may attempt the same skill check. Alternatively, one character may take the lead while another provides help, granting advantage on the roll.For group checks, everyone involved will roll. The lowest roll is discarded (when 6+ players are rolling), and the majority result will generally determine the outcome, adjusted as needed for the narrative situation.We use standard 5e resting rules. A short rest is at least 1 hour of downtime during which you can spend Hit Dice to regain hit points. A long rest is at least 8 hours of rest including sleep. After a long rest you regain all hit points and some Hit Dice back. You can benefit from only one long rest per 24 hours.
For full details see the official Basic Rules: https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/dnd/basic-rules-2014/adventuring#Resting

Resting and Health Regeneration

player/sessions/session-0/character-conc.title: Character Concepts From Each Player
player/sessions/session-0/character-conc.description: Player Name: ___4) Character Pitch (one sentence) “I am a __ who __.”Examples: “I am a runaway acolyte who still hears my god in my dreams.” “I am a practical hunter who does not trust magic, but needs it.” DM TODO: add results to Player Characters (PCs) 5) Three Tags Pick 3: Protector Survivor Scholar Trickster Zealot Outcast Leader Caretaker Daredevil Loyalist Rebel Greedy (but redeemable) 6) Spotlight Preference Circle one: I like being central sometimes I prefer supporting others I want a mix 7) One Signature Thing About Your Character Pick one: A signature spell: __ A signature weapon style: __ A signature tool or kit: __ A signature animal companion vibe Write it: ___ 8) Two Noncombat Moves -- meant to help guide your character action (choices must make sense) Pick two: I can talk my way into places I can sneak and scout I can heal or stabilize reliably I can solve mysteries (investigation, insight) I can navigate wilderness I can craft or repair I can read magic or detect danger

player/sessions/session-0/player-point-b.title: Player Point Buy Worksheet
player/sessions/session-0/player-point-b.description:
9) Point Buy Stats Strength is crushing a tomato.
Dexterity is dodging the tomato when someone throws it at you.
Constitution is eating a rotten one and not being ill because of it.
Intelligence is knowing a tomato is a fruit
Wisdom is knowing not to put it in a fruit salad.
Charisma is convincing people to buy your tomato-based fruit salad.D&D 5e Point Buy Cost Table
Point buy in D&D 5e gives you 27 points to spend on your six ability scores before racial bonuses.You cannot raise a score above 15 before racial bonuses. Once the 27 points are spent, you apply racial bonuses, pick your class, and you are done. This ensures everyone starts balanced while still choosing what their character is good at and where they are weaker.When creating your character in D&D Beyond, please follow these steps exactly.
Create or open your character.
Go to the Abilities section.
Under Generation Method, select Point Buy.
You will see all ability scores start at 8 and a pool of 27 points.
Use the plus and minus buttons to raise or lower scores. You cannot raise any score above 15 before racial bonuses. Once you have spent all 27 points, stop.
Apply your racial bonuses automatically when prompted.
Do not roll for stats and do not use standard array.
That’s it. If you get stuck, stop and we will finish it together in Session 0.

headers.heading: Example 5e Point Buy Spends by Class Type (27 Points)
Player Instructions: Using Point Buy in D&D Beyond

player/sessions/session-0/table-setup-an.title: Table Setup and Expectations
player/sessions/session-0/table-setup-an.description:
1) Campaign Tone
Circle one: Cozy heroic Classic heroic with danger Dark fairy tale with hope Grim and morally messy 2) Party Contract
Answer yes or no:
We are a cooperative party (no sabotage): Y / N
Secrets between characters are allowed if they create story not conflict: Y / N
PvP is only allowed with prior consent: Y / N
Party splits will be kept short and rare: Y / N
3) Safety and Boundaries Non-Negotiable:
No harm to children
No sexual violence of any kind
Party Discussion:
Fade to black for romance
Avoid torture detail
Other: ___

player/sessions/session-0.html.title: Session 0
player/sessions/session-0.html.description:
Most of this Session 0 will include some in-class homework with teacher supervision ;) ... All the places where you see a * will have a worksheet printed for you to fill out as we work through the session on Feb 1 2025.Pre Session 0 Homework (easiest you'll ever have): Make sure I have your contact info (SMS/EMAIL) Pick your character class (think everyone has this done) Pick a character Name Pick a visual description for your character (can be as simple or as complex as you like I'm going to dump these in GPT to get some pics of you hooligans) Install DnD Beyond Client ahead to save time, I can help in session if you need https://www.dndbeyond.com/player-app
World and Story Overview Read through (2 mins)
Table Setup and Expectation (10 mins)
Team Building * (10 Mins)Technical DND Beyond Setup for each player (20 mins): Setup DnD Beyond Accounts Install/Configure DnD Beyond App on phones/iPad as needed with tech support ;) Walk through of Character Creation on DnD Beyond Website
Character Concepts From Each Player * (15-25 mins)
Player Point Buy Worksheet - * (5-10 mins)
Equipment Selection - * (5-10 mins)
Party Weaving - * (10 mins)
House Rules - (10-15 mins)I'd like to have you each work on a character backstory for session 1, please connect with me for any questions you might have about this, and I'm happy to give as much or as little guidance as you wish. Your characters will all be meeting each other for the first time in Session 1, unless you work out a pre-existing character relationship with me ahead.Based on the input I've received so far we will aim for first Sunday of every month, remind me to make sure we cover this with the group before we leave a session! Let's discuss:A session will be canceled or rescheduled if... ❏ the DM is absent. ❏ ___ players are absent. ❏The goal at the table is for everyone to have fun and feel comfortable participating.Side conversations and discussion are fine as long as they are not disruptive. Engagement is more important than strict silence, and collaborative moments are encouraged.Phones and devices are welcome at the table and are expected to be used primarily for character sheets, rules reference, and notes. If an important call or message comes in, it is completely fine to step away briefly to take it.Please be mindful of shared spotlight time and give others space to contribute. If something is unclear or not working for you, speak up. This is a cooperative game, and we will adjust as needed. Food will be allowed at the table. If you have any allergies that we don't know about now would be a great time to mention it. Alcohol will be allowed at the table, you are your own liquor control board, no drinking and driving. Let's Discuss: How much narrative control players have (I'm very much interested in players adding to the story). Take backs, or retconning, will be permitted when... ● the DM misrepresents a scene or creature, rule. ● a player describes their character’s actions as an obvious joke. ● the player has not completed their turn Discuss: Player-vs-player action is acceptable... ❏ during social interactions ❏ during combat ❏ never ❏ Discuss any RPG pet peeves that have not yet been addressed Discuss the “rating” of your typical game: G, PG, PG-13, R, X. I expect given the players at this table the rating will be at times R rated. If there is any topic you want to keep out of the game please let me know either in session or privately I have no problem adding hard rules about anything that makes anyone uncomfortable. This campaign is to have fun to make anyone uncomfortable. I want you all to feel that you can provide feedback, however I would like to keep it primarily out of play sessions as I would like to make this as immersive a campaign as I can muster for you all, this can be done through discussion at the beginning or end of a session, or via text, that said questions about game mechanics etc. are welcome anytime I know we have some new players.Does anyone have any questions or concerns about anything we discussed today?

player/world-and-story-overview.html.title: World and Story Overview
player/world-and-story-overview.html.description: This campaign is set in Averwyn, a settled and civilized land where roads are maintained, trade flows steadily, and laws provide structure to daily life. For most people, Averwyn feels predictable, orderly, and safe. Communities are stable. Institutions function. Problems are expected to be handled properly.You will begin as ordinary adventurers, not legends or chosen heroes. Your early experiences will be grounded and local. Small jobs, personal requests, and practical concerns will shape your first steps into the world.Averwyn favors structure and process. When disputes arise, there are rules for resolving them. When authority is involved, it is typically calm, professional, and confident in its procedures. This creates a sense of reliability, though not every decision feels personal, and not every outcome feels entirely satisfying.The campaign emphasizes people, choices, and consequences rather than constant combat. Violence exists, but it is not always the best or easiest solution. Conversations, investigations, and judgment calls often matter just as much as swords and spells.As you travel through Averwyn and interact with its people, you may begin to notice patterns. Customs that are widely accepted. Rules that seem reasonable in isolation. Outcomes that do not affect everyone equally. What those patterns mean, and how much they matter, is something your characters will discover through play.There is no single expected path. You may pursue personal goals, take on responsibility, seek influence, or simply try to live well within the world as it is. The story will respond to what you engage with and what you choose to leave untouched.This is a character driven campaign. Your backgrounds, values, and reactions will shape how Averwyn responds to you. The tone is grounded, sometimes warm, sometimes tense, and always shaped by consequence.

player/rules/alignment.html.title: Alignment
player/rules/alignment.html.description: Alignment is a tool to help describe a character’s values and instincts. It is not a straightjacket, and it does not dictate every decision your character makes. People are inconsistent, and characters are allowed to be as well.Alignment should guide how your character tends to act under pressure, not how they behave in every moment.Characters do not need to share the same alignment to work together, but they should be capable of cooperating with the party.

player/rules/hit-point-increases-in-d&d-.title: Hit Point Increases in D&D 5e
player/rules/hit-point-increases-in-d&d-.description:
At 1st level, characters gain the maximum value of their class Hit Die plus their Constitution modifier.At each level after 1st, a character chooses one of the following:
Roll their class Hit Die and add their Constitution modifier
Take the fixed average value of their class Hit Die and add their Constitution modifier
This choice can be made each time you level up. However once you roll the choice is made for that level, it is final, you cannot drop back to the median after the fact. These averages are rounded up, which slightly favors consistency over risk.

headers.heading: Fixed Average Values by Hit Die

player/sessions/session-0/team-building..title: Team Building
player/sessions/session-0/team-building..description:
What’s one thing you love about RPGs? This could be a favorite
moment from a previous campaign, why they’re excited to play
(strategy, story, social interaction), or anything else. Are you most excited by combat, exploration and puzzles,
or roleplay? As a player, what’s one strength you bring to the group?
If someone can’t think of their own strengths, let others share
a strength they see in that player! Question 1 Answers:Question 2 Answers:Question 3 Answers:

player/pcs/elowenya-amberwyn.html.title: Elowenya Amberwyn
player/pcs/elowenya-amberwyn.html.description: Appearance: Elowyn Amberwyn is an Autumn Eladrin with chestnut-brown hair, warm fair skin, and moss-green eyes touched with gold. Her delicate, fey features and pointed ears give her an air of quiet grace, and she favors earth-toned clothing and simple, elegant jewelry. When she uses magic, soft amber light and drifting autumn leaves seem to gather around her. Vibe or Presence: How Others Likely See Them: At a glance, she seems gentle, thoughtful, and composed, with a scholar’s posture rather than a showy mage’s swagger. She reads as someone who listens before speaking, weighs her words, and notices details others miss. There’s a softness to her—warm autumn tones rather than blazing fire—that suggests patience, empathy, and restraint.

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
